title: POLITICO Playbook: D.C. stays in the fight
text:
POLITICO Playbook: D.C. stays in the fight Presented by

There’s a lot to learn from the Nats, a team that was counted out by just about everyone during its struggles. | Patrick Smith/Getty Images

DRIVING THE DAY

HEY, WASHINGTON … Good Wednesday morning. For the first time since 1933, you’re waking up in a World Series town. Even if the Washington Nationals aren’t your team, this might be your city, so soak it in. There’s a lot to learn from the Nats, a team that was counted out by just about everyone during its struggles. But, for now, listen to the great philosopher DAVEY MARTINEZ (he’s the manager, if the Nats aren’t your thing): “Often, bumpy roads lead to beautiful places, and this is a beautiful place.”

WASHINGTON POST SPORTS FRONT: “Nationals’ league” … Front-page image

-- THE WORLD SERIES begins Tuesday on the road. The World Series comes to Washington next weekend -- Oct. 25-Oct. 27.

SPOTTED: Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) and Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh separately at the game Tuesday night. Pic of Brown … Pic of Kavanaugh

IMPEACHMENT TODAY … MICHAEL MCKINLEY, the former senior adviser to Secretary of State MIKE POMPEO, will testify before the House Oversight/Intelligence/Foreign Affairs committees.

-- WHAT DEMS ARE LOOKING FOR: Democrats tell us that McKinley has firsthand knowledge of the inner workings of the State Department. He can speak to the morale and administration strategy in Foggy Bottom.

REPUBLICANS, MEANWHILE, seemed a bit confounded in how they’ll approach McKinley. A few told us they had no idea what he would say, and didn’t know much about him. One GOP lawmaker mentioned that they are going to try to press him on whether he sought out derogatory information from other State employees to denigrate President DONALD TRUMP.

INTERNAL AFFAIRS … NYT: “White House Is Said to Open Internal Review of Ukraine Call,” by Julian Barnes, Maggie Haberman and Mike Schmidt: “President Trump has for weeks sought to unmask the whistle-blower who shed light on his Ukraine dealings. But instead aides have fixated on one another: Advisers began a fact-finding review that some fear is a hunt for a scapegoat, according to White House aides and other people familiar with it.

“Even as the impeachment inquiry intensifies in Congress, White House lawyers are leading their own review, the people said. They are seeking to understand White House officials’ actions around Mr. Trump’s July 25 call with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, which is central to the whistle-blower’s allegation that Mr. Trump abused his power.

“The lawyers’ inquiry centers on why one of their colleagues, the deputy White House counsel John A. Eisenberg, placed a rough transcript of the call in a computer system typically reserved for the country’s most closely guarded secrets. Mr. Trump later directed that a reconstructed transcript be released amid intensifying scrutiny from House Democrats.” NYT

-- “Bolton, Mulvaney on Opposite Sides of Pivotal Ukraine Debate,” by WSJ’s Michael Bender and Rebecca Ballhaus: “The two aides who missed the call — Mick Mulvaney and John Bolton — represented two poles of a fierce internal White House debate over an issue now at the center of a House impeachment inquiry: Mr. Trump’s dealings with Ukraine. ...

“Mr. Mulvaney, the acting chief of staff and director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, carried out the president’s order to suspend nearly $400 million in military aid to Ukraine. Mr. Bolton, who has since resigned as national security adviser, protested the move and — before the hold on the money was lifted — promised Ukrainian officials during a visit to Kyiv in August that the U.S. wouldn’t revoke it.” WSJ

-- WAPO: “White House directed ‘three amigos’ to run Ukraine policy, senior State department official tells House investigators,” by Paul Kane, Karoun Demirjian and Rachael Bade: “Acting White House chief of staff Mick Mulvaney organized a meeting this spring in which officials were determined to take Ukraine policy out of the traditional channels, putting Energy Secretary Rick Perry, U.S. Ambassador to the European Union Gordon Sondland and special U.S. envoy to Ukraine Kurt Volker in charge instead, a top State Department official told lawmakers Tuesday.

“George Kent, the deputy assistant secretary of state responsible for Ukraine, told House investigators he was instructed to “lay low,” focus on the five other countries in his portfolio and defer to Volker, Sondland and Perry — who called themselves the ‘three amigos’ — on matters related to Ukraine, Rep. Gerald E. Connolly (D-Va.) told reporters Tuesday. Kent took that as a sign, Connolly added, that having been critical of the plan he was being pushed aside ‘because what he was saying was not welcome’ at high levels of the government.” WaPo

A message from USAA: Military and veteran caregivers wear many hats when caring for our nation’s wounded warriors at home. USAA recognizes the selflessness of these 5.5 million hidden heroes and supports efforts to connect them with resources to help ease their load. Learn More.

THE LEADERSHIP BACKS OFF … FOR NOW -- “Pelosi holds off on vote to authorize Trump impeachment inquiry,” by John Bresnahan, Heather Caygle and Sarah Ferris: “Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Democratic leaders will hold off on a full House vote authorizing an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, according to multiple lawmakers and aides.

“Democratic leadership sources caution, however, that the decision could be ‘reassessed at some point.’ The move came amid opposition from key chairmen and members of leadership, as well as a number of centrist Democrats facing tough reelection bids.” POLITICO

THE PENTAGON said it recognizes “the significance” of the Democrats’ request for documents, but the Defense Department would not fork any over. The letter

-- TUESDAY WAS AN INTERESTING DAY on this front. There were reports early yesterday -- from POLITICO and NBC -- that House Democratic leadership was calling around, sounding lawmakers out about a vote to authorize the impeachment inquiry. Pelosi was asked about it, and said she would address it later in the day.

THEN, IN THE LATE AFTERNOON, Dem leadership was getting ready to meet, and House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer told us on his way into the room that it was going to be discussed in the meeting. While they were in that meeting, Pelosi’s team alerted a news conference at 6:30 p.m. -- a rare time for a press event, especially on a Tuesday with Congress just back in session. The Hill press corps thought news was coming. Then, our aforementioned colleagues Bres, Heather and Sarah reported that no, Pelosi would not allow a vote, setting up a quite anticlimactic press conference. (Note: Pelosi invited House Intel Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.) to participate in the news conference with her, and sat in the seats with reporters for part of the event.)

ONE COULD ARGUE the wisdom of such a vote in either direction -- and many of our sources have. TRUMP’s White House and its allies said he would not participate in impeachment without such a vote -- so, by holding a vote, Democrats could take away this excuse. And it would arguably be a tough vote for some Republicans who have privately complained that they don’t know where this story ends for Trump. But it would also be a tough vote for some Democrats. And there are many Democrats who believe holding a vote would amount to allowing the president and Republicans to dictate their actions.

PELOSI, at that news conference: “All roads seem to lead to Putin with the president, though, isn’t it so?”

DEBATE RECAP …

-- THE FACTS OF LIFE: “Warren's charmed campaign just entered a brutal new phase,” by Ryan Lizza in Westerville, Ohio: “Elizabeth Warren has enjoyed many of the trappings of a front-runner: the polling lead in Iowa and New Hampshire, a near-tie with Joe Biden nationally, explosive fundraising, big crowds. The only thing missing was the scrutiny and sniping from competitors that normally accompanies the rise of a new primary leader.

“That changed on Tuesday night at Otterbein University, a small college outside Columbus, Ohio. Otterbein was named after the founder of the United Brethren in Christ, but the mood was anything but brotherly as Warren faced a barrage of criticisms from most of the other 11 Democrats on stage.

“The candidate who brags about having a plan for everything was pilloried for not detailing how she would pay for her most expensive proposal. She was accused — sometimes subtly, sometimes explicitly — of being naive, dishonest, not adequately respecting her colleagues’ ideas, tearing people down, and failing to enact major legislation. She was attacked for believing in policies that were ‘punitive’ and a theory of governing that was a ‘pipe dream.’

“Warren’s biggest gains have come since the last debate, so Tuesday's debate was the natural point for a more full-throated engagement from the other candidates.” POLITICO … Check out Eugene Daniels’ recap video of the attacks on Warren

-- JOHN HARRIS on the two new dynamics at play Tuesday night: “The first was the degree of critical focus on Sen. Elizabeth Warren, reflecting a calculation that she, rather than former Vice President Joe Biden, has the momentum in the race and is setting the agenda for the party. She took in the glare for the largest share of the three-hour debate without wilting, or receding for significant chunks of the evening (as she did in previous encounters) when the issues shifted away from terrain where she is most comfortable.

“The second dynamic was an honest illumination of the party’s left-vs.-center debate. In past encounters, this conversation often was portrayed as a choice between ‘activists’ and ‘establishment,’ or between bold principles and expedient moderation.” POLITICO

-- WAPO’S DAN BALZ: “The Democratic debates haven’t changed much? Oh, yes they have.”

-- “What heart attack? Bernie bounces back at debate,” by Holly Otterbein in Westerville

Playbook PM Sign up for our must-read newsletter on what's driving the afternoon in Washington. Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

PENCE AND POMPEO TO TURKEY: PLEASE STOP THE WAR THAT YOU GAVE US A HEADS-UP ON AND YOU JUST STARTED! … NYT: “Pence and Pompeo to Push Erdogan for Pullback From Syria,” by Katie Rogers and Eric Schmitt: “Vice President Mike Pence and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will meet with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Ankara on Thursday to relay President Trump’s demand that Mr. Erdogan negotiate a cease-fire in Syria and to reiterate the president’s threat to impose economic sanctions if he does not comply.

“The president’s sending of the delegation — to also include his national security adviser, Robert C. O’Brien, and the State Department’s special envoy for Syrian affairs, James F. Jeffrey — is part of a scrambled effort to wrest back control of a chaotic situation in Syria that has endangered American forces there even as they prepared to leave. …

“Mr. Trump has long viewed his personal relationships with leaders, including Mr. Erdogan, as key to accomplishing his foreign policy goals. But Mr. Trump’s failure in an Oct. 6 phone call to outline the consequences for Mr. Erdogan if he moved his troops into Syria has forced the White House to deal with the consequences.” NYT

… UH, GUYS, DID YOU READ THIS? -- REUTERS: “Erdogan says Turkey will never declare ceasefire in northern Syria”: “‘They say “declare a ceasefire.” We will never declare a ceasefire,’ Erdogan said. ‘They are pressuring us to stop the operation. They are announcing sanctions. Our goal is clear. We are not worried about any sanctions,’ he said.” Reuters

THE BREAKING POINT NO LONGER … “Republicans buckle to Trump on Syria,” by Burgess Everett, Melanie Zanona and Marianne LeVine: “The Republican rebellion against President Donald Trump was short-lived.

“Republicans unleashed perhaps their most aggressive outcry of the Trump era after he abandoned the U.S.’s Kurdish allies and ceded northeastern Syria to Turkey. But now GOP lawmakers are dialing back their direct criticism of the president — instead working with Trump, dinging Democrats and trying to move forward.”

HAPPENING TODAY -- Trump will meet with Republican and Democratic leadership, as well as the chairs and ranking members of the Foreign Relations and Armed Services committees, at the White House at 3 p.m. to discuss Turkey. It will be the first time Pelosi has met with Trump since launching the impeachment inquiry. NOT INVITED: Intel Committee chairs and ranking members.

2020 WATCH …

-- BIG FOR BERNIE: “Ocasio-Cortez to endorse Bernie Sanders,” by Abbey Marshall: “Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez plans to endorse Bernie Sanders at a campaign rally on Saturday, according to two Sanders aides, strengthening the Vermont senator’s pull among young liberals.” POLITICO

-- HMM … “Warren rakes in tech donations as she pledges to break up donors’ companies,” by Maggie Severns

A message from USAA: Military and veteran caregivers wear many hats when caring for our nation’s wounded warriors at home. USAA recognizes the selflessness of these 5.5 million hidden heroes and supports efforts to connect them with resources to help ease their load. Learn More.

TRUMP’S WEDNESDAY -- Trump will participate in the arrival of Italian President Sergio Mattarella at 10:15 a.m. in the South Portico. He will participate in a bilateral meeting with Mattarella at 10:25 in the Oval Office followed by an expanded bilateral meeting in the Cabinet Room. The two will hold a joint press conference at noon in the East Room. Trump will have lunch with Pompeo at 12:45 p.m. in the private dining room. He will meet with congressional leadership at 3 in the Cabinet Room.

Trump will participate in the arrival of Mattarella at 6:15 and will give remarks at a reception in honor of Italy at 6:30 in the East Room.

PLAYBOOK READS

PHOTO DU JOUR: The ultimate D.C. split screen Tuesday night at Hawk ‘n’ Dove: the Nationals making their way to the World Series on one TV, the Democratic debate on the other. | Nick Wass/AP Photo

DAILY RUDY -- “Giuliani pressed Trump to eject Muslim cleric from U.S., a top priority of Turkish president, former officials say,” by WaPo’s Carol Leonnig, Ellen Nakashima, Josh Dawsey and Tom Hamburger: “Rudolph W. Giuliani privately urged President Trump in 2017 to extradite a Turkish cleric living in exile in the United States, a top priority of Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, according to multiple former administration officials familiar with the discussions.

“Giuliani, a Trump ally who later became the president’s personal attorney, repeatedly argued to Trump that the U.S. government should eject Fethullah Gulen from the country, according to the former officials, who spoke on the condition on anonymity to describe private conversations.

“Turkey has demanded that the United States turn over Gulen, a permanent U.S. resident who lives in Pennsylvania, to stand trial on charges of plotting a 2016 coup attempt against Erdogan. Gulen has denied involvement in the plot.” WaPo

WHAT THE? … “Trump's ‘China Muse’ Has an Imaginary Friend,” by The Chronicle of Higher Education’s Tom Bartlett: “Who is Ron Vara? He only seems to exist in the books of Peter Navarro … What does Peter Navarro have to say about his imaginary friend? I emailed the White House press office and received a phone call from Navarro. While he declined to speak on the record, he did send a statement in which he called Ron Vara a ‘whimsical device and pen name I’ve used throughout the years for opinions and purely entertainment value, not as a source of fact.’

“He compared the Ron Vara character to ‘Alfred Hitchcock appearing briefly in cameo in his movies’ and wrote that it's ‘refreshing that somebody finally figured out an inside joke that has been hiding in plain sight for years.’” Chronicle

TRADE WARS -- “China Threatens to Retaliate If U.S. Enacts Hong Kong Bill,” by Bloomberg’s Iain Marlow, Daniel Flatley and Dandan Li: “China threatened unspecified ‘strong countermeasures’ if the U.S. Congress enacts legislation supporting Hong Kong protesters, in a sign of the deepening strain between the world’s two largest economies as they attempt to seal a trade deal.

“China’s foreign ministry issued the warning Wednesday after the U.S. House passed a package of measures backing a pro-democracy movement that has rocked the former British colony for more than four months. Among them was the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, which subjects the city’s special U.S. trading status to annual reviews and provides for sanctions against officials deemed responsible for undermining its ‘fundamental freedoms and autonomy.’” Bloomberg

LITTLE ROCKET MAN -- “Kim Jong Un, Astride a Pale Horse, Urges Self Reliance in Face of U.S. Sanctions,” by WSJ’s Timothy Martin and Dasl Yoon in Seoul: “Mr. Kim’s comments suggest Pyongyang’s hardened stance on nuclear talks with Washington isn’t softening. Working-level negotiations broke off earlier this month in Sweden. The Kim regime has since threatened to end diplomacy unless Washington takes a substantial step toward Pyongyang’s position before the end of the year.” WSJ

TRUMP, INC. -- “Never-Before-Seen Trump Tax Documents Show Major Inconsistencies,” by ProPublica’s Heather Vogell: “Documents obtained by ProPublica show stark differences in how Donald Trump’s businesses reported some expenses, profits and occupancy figures for two Manhattan buildings, giving a lender different figures than they provided to New York City tax authorities. The discrepancies made the buildings appear more profitable to the lender — and less profitable to the officials who set the buildings’ property tax.

“For instance, Trump told the lender that he took in twice as much rent from one building as he reported to tax authorities during the same year, 2017. He also gave conflicting occupancy figures for one of his signature skyscrapers, located at 40 Wall Street.” ProPublica

BEYOND THE BELTWAY -- “Amazon drops additional $1 million-plus into Seattle City Council races, with ballots out this week,” by The Seattle Times’ Daniel Beekman and Jim Brunner: “Amazon is dropping an additional $1 million-plus into Seattle’s pivotal City Council races, boosting its spending on politics in its hometown this year to an unprecedented $1.45 million. ...

“Amazon’s outlay is the largest ‘in anyone’s memory’ by a single entity in a Seattle election cycle, said Wayne Barnett, executive director of the Seattle Ethics and Elections Commission. The record-breaking sum is the latest sign that the company with 53,000 local employees, once content to stay on the political sidelines, is now throwing its weight around.” Seattle Times

POLITICO Playbook newsletter Sign up today to receive the #1-rated newsletter in politics Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

CONWAY VS. CONWAY … THE CENTER FOR PUBLIC INTEGRITY’S CARRIE LEVINE (@levinecarrie): “Joe Walsh’s presidential campaign took in $235K, including $100K in a loan from Walsh himself - and $5,600, the maximum contribution allowable, from lawyer George Conway.”

VALLEY TALK -- “Facebook Said Politicians Can Lie In Ads. It's Taking Down Ads From Warren, Biden, And Trump For Other Reasons,” by BuzzFeed’s Ryan Mac and Zahra Hirji: “According to a BuzzFeed News review, Facebook has removed more than 160 ads posted this month by President Donald Trump and some Democratic candidates, including Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, former vice president Joe Biden, and businessperson Tom Steyer.

“In some cases, Facebook appeared to apply its policies unequally, removing some ads for breaking rules around profanity, fake buttons, and advertising in certain states while leaving others that seemed to do the exact same thing untouched.” BuzzFeed

MEDIAWATCH -- “ProPublica and Texas Tribune joining forces to create new investigative unit,” by CNN’s Brian Stelter: “The long-term commitment is made possible by a $5.75 million donation from Arnold Ventures, a fund run by John D. and Laura Arnold. He is a billionaire philanthropist who formerly traded for Enron and ran his own hedge fund.” CNN … The announcement

-- TV TONIGHT: Ronan Farrow goes on Fox News for the first time to discuss his new book, “Catch and Kill.”

-- “Twitter says it wants to solve the ‘journalists’ careers end because someone digs up an old tweet’ problem” by Nieman Lab’s Joshua Benton

PLAYBOOKERS

SPOTTED: Eric Cantor walking through Union Station on Tuesday. Pic … Wesley Clark seated in first class on an American Airlines flight from DCA to Little Rock, Ark., on Tuesday.

OUT AND ABOUT -- SPOTTED at a party Tuesday night at Akin Gump celebrating Lawrence Jackson’s new book “Yes We Did” ($28 on Amazon), with a foreword by former President Barack Obama: Sen. Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) and Marcelle Leahy, Chris Dodd, Ed Pagano, Tom Quinn, Matt Gerson, Joe Paulsen, Eric Waldo, Michael Smith, Brian Mosteller, Chynna Clayton, Sam Tubman, Terry Szuplat, Chris Ortman, Tom Zigo and Rishi Sahgal.

-- SPOTTED at a reception for the launch of Greta Van Susteren’s new Sunday show, “Full Court Press,” and Gray Television’s D.C. bureau’s fifth anniversary on the rooftop of 101 Constitution, hosted by CEO Hilton Howell: Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai, Sens. John Thune (R-S.D.), John Barrasso (R-Wyo.), Roger Wicker (R-Miss.), Rick Scott (R-Fla.), Kevin Cramer (R-N.D.), Deb Fischer (R-Neb.), James Lankford (R-Okla.) and Marsha Blackburn (R-Tenn.), House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, Reps. Donna Shalala (D-Fla.), Dutch Ruppersberger (D-Md.), Danny Davis (D-Ill.), Billy Long (R-Mo.), Garret Graves (R-La.), Kelly Armstrong (R-N.D.), Jim Hagedorn (R-Minn.), Dusty Johnson (R-S.D.) and Debbie Lesko (R-Ariz.) …

… Margery Kraus, Martin O’Malley, Robert Costa, Phil Rucker, Carol Melton, Shawna Thomas, Jacqueline Policastro, Patricia Harrison, Monica Crowley, John McCarthy, Hilary Rosen, Dan Meyers, Jeremy and Robyn Bash, Jim Moran, Roberta and Joe McCain, Kevin Latek, Betsy Fischer Martin, Bob Crowe, Kimberley Fritts, Heather Podesta, Tammy Haddad, Kent Knutson, Ryan Williams, Caroline Decker, Ruth Marcus, Amanda Bennett, Liz Johnson, Anita McBride, Pam Bondi, Megan Whittemore and Lise Van Susteren. Pic

TRANSITIONS -- Alan McQuinn is now a professional staff member at the House Science Committee. He previously was a senior policy analyst at the Information Technology and Innovation Foundation. … Cub Barrett is now SVP for health policy at the Corkery Group. He previously was VP of communications and public affairs at GMHC.

BIRTHDAY OF THE DAY: Rep. André Carson (D-Ind.) is 45. A fun fact about him: “I’ve had a lot of interesting and unique jobs. Some people may already know that I was a rapper when I was younger who once opened for Ice Cube, or that I was in law enforcement. But I also used to help run a youth center, and I was certified to remove asbestos at one time. Life has taken me on many interesting turns, but I’m glad it eventually led me to Congress, where I’m honored to stand up for Hoosiers at the highest levels of government.” Playbook Q&A

BIRTHDAYS: Sarah Westwood, White House reporter for CNN (hat tip: Melissa Brown) … Michael Pratt, director of strategic comms at HHS, is 3-0 … Jim Courtovich … former North Dakota Gov. Jack Dalrymple is 71 … Jenny Hopkinson … Beatrice Peterson … former Rep. Tom MacArthur (R-N.J.) is 59 … former Rep. Dave Trott (R-Mich.) is 59 … Rodell Mollineau, partner at Rokk Solutions (h/t Ron Bonjean) … Ben Coffey Clark, partner at Bully Pulpit Interactive (h/ts Tim Burger) … USA Today’s Alex Lemley … John Goodwin is 41 … Dan Hirschhorn … Steve Friess is 47 … Deloitte’s Chris Faile is 42 … Tiph Turpin … Linda Miller (h/ts Jon Haber) … WaPo’s Andrew Heining … Frank Green … Ryan Walters … Tim Flynn … Matt Koch … Alex MacFarlane, comms director for Rep. Mike Thompson (D-Calif.) …

… Tyler Evans, digital media coordinator for Bernie Sanders’ campaign … FT’s Brendan Greeley is 45 … former SEC Chairman Christopher Cox is 67 … USAID’s Daniel Henke … Phil Bianchi, public policy specialist at Squire Patton Boggs, is 32 (h/t fiancee Lauren Aronson) … Lindi Harvey ... Dan Gross, senior adviser for citywide events for New York Mayor Bill de Blasio ... Ivette Fernandez, VP of government relations at Endeavor … Bradley Becnel ... Garrett Murch … Vanessa Dennis ... Deloitte’s Kristen McGrath Dugan ... Delacey Skinner ... Nate Morris … Avi Fink … Devora Kaye ... Bruce Plaxen ... Emily Karl ... Alexandra Fetissoff … Elizabeth McGreevy … Becca Milfeld ... Ric Arenstein ... Jim Pribyl ... Mark Bohannon ... Jeff Link (h/ts Teresa Vilmain)

A message from USAA: Military and veteran caregivers must wear many hats when caring for our nation’s wounded warriors at home. In addition to being spouses, parents, children or friends of the servicemember or veteran, caregivers also step up and serve as doctors, nurses, therapists, financial planners, drivers and more. In some cases, they even set aside their own careers to care for those who served our nation. According to the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, 25% of caregivers spend more than 40 hours per week fulfilling this responsibility. And caregivers are often silent about their responsibilities. USAA recognizes the selflessness of these 5.5 million hidden heroes and backs efforts to connect them with resources and networks of support to help ease their load. Learn More.

Follow us on Twitter Anna Palmer @apalmerdc



Jake Sherman @JakeSherman
description: And the Democratic debate centers on Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.).
